metadata.titleEn: Integrated environment observation data of base camp in Hulugou sub-basin of Heihe River Basin (2012)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview
The data set of the base camp integrated environmental observation system is a set of ENVIS (IMKO, Germany) which was installed at the base camp observation point by qilian station.It is stored automatically by ENVIS data mining system.
2. Data content
This data set is the scale data from January 1, 2012 to December 31, 2012.Including air temperature 1.5m, humidity 1.5m, air temperature 2.5m, humidity 2.5m, soil moisture 0cm, precipitation, wind speed 1.5m, wind speed 2.5m, wind direction 1.5m, geothermal flux 5cm, total radiation, surface temperature, ground temperature 20cm, ground temperature 40cm, ground temperature 60cm, ground temperature 80cm, ground temperature 120cm, ground temperature 160cm, CO2, air pressure.
3. Space and time scope
Geographical coordinates: longitude: 99° 53’e;Latitude: 38°16 'N;Height: 2980.2 m.
metadata.instructions: Data file name: hulugou basin 2012 base camp integrated environmental observation system data set.xlsx; it can be viewed and edited by WPS or excel and other software.

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Example.Question: What is an example of the challenges faced in cryospheric hydrology data collection in remote mountainous areas?
Example.Answer: One significant challenge in understanding cryospheric hydrology changes in remote mountainous areas is the sparse and biased precipitation observations. The remoteness of these regions makes it difficult to acquire accurate data, which affects the understanding of hydrological processes.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of a dataset that has been utilized to study the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff?
Example.Answer: In recent years, data from the CHOICE sharing platform has been used to study cryospheric hydrology. This includes observations from six AWS across the Hulu catchment and supplemental data from peripheral China Meteorological Administration stations, which have been used to assess changes in stream flow and the impacts of cryospheric changes over a decade.

Definition.Question: What does 'ENVIS综合环境观测系统' refer to in the context of environmental data collection in alpine regions?
Definition.Answer: ENVIS综合环境观测系统 refers to a comprehensive environmental observation system used to automatically store data collected by an ENVIS data collection system installed at a base camp observation point, capturing various environmental parameters.

Definition.Question: What does 'AWS' stand for in the context of long-term meteorological monitoring?
Definition.Answer: AWS stands for Automatic Weather Station, which is used for long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, wind speed, and precipitation in alpine catchments.

Comparison.Question: How do automatic weather stations (AWS) compare to manual weighing microlysimeters in terms of data collection efficiency for alpine meteorology studies?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic weather stations (AWS) enable continuous and long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and radiation, providing extensive datasets with minimal manual intervention. In contrast, manual weighing microlysimeters, although precise, require more frequent manual operation and are thus less efficient for large-scale or continuous data collection.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed biases and errors in precipitation data collection affect the interpretation of hydrological models in alpine catchments?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed biases and errors in precipitation data collection can significantly affect the interpretation of hydrological models by introducing inaccuracies in the estimation of water resources, which is crucial for understanding the hydrological balance in alpine catchments.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation from the data collected by rain-weighing sensors and pit gauges?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collected by rain-weighing sensors and pit gauges can help infer the spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation, which is essential for determining the effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow and water resources in mountainous areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes significant challenges in understanding changes in vulnerable regions within cryospheric hydrology?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The remoteness and sparse observations in these regions, along with significant biases and errors in precipitation observations, pose significant challenges.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the lack of knowledge about cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inadequate observation data and the complexity of cryospheric changes make it difficult to fully understand cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for comprehensive observation data to determine hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Comprehensive observation data is needed to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources, especially in arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of inadequate observation data on understanding cryospheric hydrometeorology in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Inadequate observation data results in significant challenges in understanding cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales, making it difficult to assess the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences, especially in China.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind collecting comprehensive environmental data using automated weather stations in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and assess the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on hydrology and water resources in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to employ multiple methods for measuring soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in alpine catchments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is significant to employ multiple methods to ensure accuracy and reliability in measuring soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity, which are critical for understanding water movement and storage in soil under different landscape conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to ensure the accuracy of precipitation measurements in mountainous catchments, and how are biases and errors addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Precipitation intercomparisons are conducted by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Additionally, precipitation measurements are performed with total rain-weighing sensors synchronized with automatic weather stations (AWS).

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods enable the accurate assessment of cryospheric changes' effects on mountain hydrology?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection methods such as long-term monitoring of meteorological variables, manual and automatic measurements of evapotranspiration, and the use of various instruments for monitoring snow depth, soil temperature, and moisture enable the accurate assessment of cryospheric changes’ effects on mountain hydrology.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do the challenges of sparse observations and remote locations impact the enablement of comprehensive data collection in alpine catchments?
Enablement.Answer: The challenges of sparse observations and remote locations impact the enablement of comprehensive data collection by introducing biases and errors in precipitation measurements, thus requiring advanced and diverse data collection techniques and instruments to ensure accuracy and reliability of the data.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant biases and errors in precipitation observations within mountainous regions?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges due to remoteness and sparse observations, leading to biases and errors in precipitation measurements.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the inadequate observation data and lack of knowledge about cryospheric hydrometeorology in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: The remoteness of the regions and sparse observations contribute to the inadequate data and lack of knowledge regarding cryospheric hydrometeorology.

Expectation.Question: Why is it necessary to install multiple types of sensors and methods for monitoring environmental factors in alpine catchments?
Expectation.Answer: Multiple sensor installations and methods are necessary to comprehensively monitor various meteorological variables, soil parameters, and hydrological processes, which help in evaluating the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on water resources.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of the data collection methods used for capturing hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods used for capturing hydrological processes in alpine regions seem comprehensive, incorporating a variety of meteorological variables, soil parameters, and precipitation measurements. The use of automated systems like AWS, as well as manual methods, provides a robust approach to data collection. However, challenges such as the remoteness of locations and potential biases in precipitation observations may affect the effectiveness and accuracy of the data collected.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can be adapted to overcome the challenges posed by remote and sparsely observed regions in cryospheric hydrology research.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods in this field are adapted to remote and sparsely observed regions by utilizing automated weather stations (AWS) and various instruments such as infrared radiometers, sonic ranging sensors, and microlysimeters to ensure continuous and comprehensive monitoring of meteorological and hydrological variables.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges in obtaining accurate precipitation data in mountainous areas with cryospheric changes.
Assertion.Answer: Obtaining accurate precipitation data in mountainous areas is challenging due to biases and errors in precipitation measurements, which are addressed using intercomparison experiments and specialized gauges like the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment and double reference intercomparison reference gauges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used for monitoring environmental factors in mountainous regions, focusing on both automated and manual methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection techniques involve automated weather stations (AWS) for long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. Manual methods include standard meteorological field observations, float protocol for stream discharge estimation, and soil parameter data collection using infiltrometers. Additionally, specific instruments like infrared radiometers, microlysimeters, and sap flow sensors are used for specialized measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in collecting accurate precipitation data in mountainous and remote regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting accurate precipitation data include significant biases and errors that arise due to the remoteness and sparse observations in these regions. The work of precipitation intercomparisons is conducted, referring to the WMO's Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment using pit gauges and double reference intercomparison gauges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets related to cryospheric hydrology and alpine meteorology.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies can include increasing the number of observational sites, integrating various types of sensors for comprehensive data collection, and employing advanced remote sensing technologies. The development of new hydrological models, as well as the use of isotopic and microbial diversity observations, can also refine datasets. Collaborative data sharing platforms and long-term monitoring initiatives contribute to dataset expansion and refinement.
